"CONTENT!  of all the blessings I possess,</br>And (thanks to heaven) my portion is not small,</br>None can more justly claim my thankfulness</br>Than thou, sweet maid, whose smile gives zest to all;</br>Therefore on thee with suppliant voice I call;</br>With thee would hide me from the world's rude strife;</br>For well I know, whatever may befall,</br>'Tis peace of mind that makes the bliss of life—</br>That thou sustain'st the soul 'mid scenes with misery rife.

"Can Fame — can Power — can Affluence display</br>The calm composure of thy modest mien?</br>Their light may dazzle in the summer day,</br>But thou alone canst cheer the wintry scene:</br>Their pomp shall be as though it ne'er had been,</br>When the dread tempest sweeps along the sky;</br>Whilst thou, in humble confidence serene,</br>Fear'st not, for He who bids the tempest fly,</br>Mighty to save and bless, thou know'st is ever nigh.

"Still be it mine, as through the quiet vale</br>Of humble life my devious course I bend,</br>When sorrows or anxieties assail,</br>To find in thee a comforter and friend:</br>Afflictions, though keen pangs their steps attend,</br>In wisdom and in love are doubtless sent,</br>And will, ere long, in full fruition end:</br>Be then my heart on this one purpose bent—</br>Whate'er my lot may be, to dwell with thee, Content."

When thus the happy feelings of my mind</br>Had been pour'd forth in artless verse and gay,</br>What time the summer sun in pride declined</br>And gave, with glance benign, his farewell ray,</br>The genius of Repose, with wildest sway,</br>Wav'd his lethean wand above my head:</br>SLEEP charm'd, at once, each restless thought away</br>And through my mind enchanting visions spread,</br>Soothing as those around th' expiring christian's bed.

Come Fancy!  aid me in the pleasing task</br>And I will bind the spirit of that dream</br>In wild poetic numbers.  Shall I ask</br>In vain thy succour for the simple theme?</br>To thee, perchance, such earnest suit may seem</br>Presumptuous from a poor and nameless bard;</br>But not unworthy dost thou sometimes deem</br>The Muse's humblest sons of thy regard,</br>Who on Parnassus' height have reap'd a proud reward.

Methought I wander'd in a region drear</br>Which seem'd, though new, familiar to mine eye;</br>No sounds save those of woe assailed my ear</br>And every breeze was burthen'd with a sigh;</br>Dark, lowering clouds hung heavy in the sky,</br>And shed a fearful gloom o'er all the vale;</br>To trace whose bounds I seem'd in vain to try—</br>My utmost stretch of sight could not prevail,</br>And I the joyless scene beheld aghast and pale.

And here and there a wretched hut appear'd</br>That seem'd th' abode of poverty and pain;</br>For not a flower its lovely head uprear'd,</br>And not a green spot deck'd the sterile plain,</br>But Desolation, frowning, held his reign</br>On every side, with unrelenting sway;</br>And, drooping there, a miserable train</br>I saw, led on by Sorrow and Dismay,</br>While Labour's stern command still urg'd them on their way.

"Alas!"  I cried, "and is it then my fate</br>Through life to sojourn in this hopeless place,</br>Where constant toil and care my course await,</br>And comfort's cheering beams shall never chase</br>The deep-drawn lines of misery from my face?</br>Despair must be my sole companion here;</br>Where'er I turn his footsteps I can trace,</br>And in his path such rueful forms appear</br>As none unmov'd can view, Disease, and Want, and Fear."

While thus my heart, with sad forboding fears</br>Opprest, was sinking into wretchedness,</br>Methought I sigh'd and wept — but sighs and tears</br>Were unavailing in that sore distress:</br>When lo!  (but how shall words of mine express</br>The wonders I beheld?)  a sudden light</br>Burst forth, and spreading through the wilderness,</br>Clear'd the thick film which dimm'd erewhile my sight,</br>And near me now I saw a Fiend in eager flight.

The murky clouds, which on the face of heaven</br>Had hitherto in gloomy stillness spread,</br>No longer slept, but in commotion driven,</br>Now roll'd in shapeless masses o'er my head,</br>And one of hugest size and blackest shade</br>Dividing gave to my astonished view</br>A form of angel mould, whose aspect shed</br>A radiant splendour the wide valley through,</br>As on a sunbeam prone towards earth she gently flew.

Her look, with all the sprightliness of spring,</br>Was mild as summer's eve; and in mine ear</br>The music of her voice still seems to ring;</br>And thus the Vision spake as she drew near:</br>"Rise, child of sorrow, cast aside thy fear,</br>And let the light of joy illume thine eye;</br>No more shall he who caus'd thy grief appear,</br>Foul Discontent; I bade the demon fly;</br>'Twas he drew forth each tear and prompted every sigh.

"He opes the source of more than half the woes</br>That sadden human life; for not alone</br>In this secluded vale does he oppose</br>The gentle reign of peace with changeless frown;</br>E'en yon high hills, which through long years have shone</br>In the unclouded beams of affluence,</br>Dark traces of his footsteps oft have shewn;</br>For, raging, like the deadly pestilence,</br>He scours the lowly plain, and lofty eminence.

"Yet, cheer thee, mourner, for the task is mine</br>To guide thy wanderings this still region through,</br>And give it in my own fair light to shine.</br>Retirement's lonely path 'tis mine to strew</br>With flowers of fragrant scent and varied hue.</br>See!  the retiring shades my look obey!</br>See!  lovelier prospects rising into view</br>Glowing in sunshine and they seem to say:—</br>A thousand joys are here!  come, quickly, come away.'"

With that CONTENT, for she it was whose smile</br>And gracious words the sudden change had wrought</br>With gentleness that well might grief beguile,</br>And looks with cheerfulness and comfort fraught,</br>Held forth her hand to me; and then, methought</br>We wandered onward; and where'er we stray'd</br>New scenes of happiness appeared, unsought;</br>At every step new wonders were display'd—</br>And as I gaz'd, I turn'd and blest the heaven-sent maid.

There Industry from early morn till eve,</br>Speeds the gay moments as they lightly pass;</br>Though wearying toil be his, he does not grieve</br>While the blythe songs of Health, a rosy lass,</br>Soften his cares, as lightly o'er the grass,</br>With Exercise, the partner of her choice,</br>She sports, and mixes with each lowly class,</br>The dwellers of the vale, whose simple joys</br>Increase whene'er they hear her pain-subduing voice.

And there, in neat and homely cottage lives</br>Domestic Happiness, a matron chaste</br>And kind, from whom the feeling breast receives</br>Such bliss as can transform a desert waste</br>Into a paradise.  Her hearth is grac'd</br>With all the charms of virtue, peace, and love—</br>Celestial flowers, but herein mercy plac'd</br>Beneath her guardian care, whose blossoms prove</br>Their native soil to be the blissful realms above.

Still as our road meandering seem'd to run,</br>The prospect brighten'd, and before us lay</br>A mount, whose gently sloping side the sun</br>IIlumin'd with his wild, departing ray;</br>More cheerful look'd the green, the flowers more gay:</br>And round its base a pure, unruffled stream,</br>With soothing murmur, wander'd on its way;</br>Like glass it shone in the refulgent beam:—</br>And all the scene was fair as guileless childhood's dream.

And then such heavenly harmony was heard</br>As bids each vain and earthly passion flee;</br>And blooming on that mount's green brow appear'd</br>A bower of amaranth, where Piety,</br>Compass'd with beings beautiful to see,</br>Faith, Hope, and holy Joy, her anthem sung;</br>Warm yet unfeign'd her fervours seem'd to be:</br>My ravish'd soul in mute attention hung</br>While through the balmy air this strain seraphic rung:
HYMN.</br>1.</br>Once more, Eternal Power, I raise</br>My voice in humble adoration;</br>Again presume to sing thy praise,</br>The theme of angels' exultation.
2.</br>Thou art my "all in all," in thee</br>My spirit finds complete fruition</br>To seek thee, my delight shall be,</br>To serve thee truly, my ambition.
3.</br>Unnumbered blessings hourly call</br>For gratitude's sincere devotion;</br>And morning light, and evenfall,</br>Shall duly witness her emotion.
4.</br>Oft do I feel how great thy love,</br>When lowly at thine altar kneeling;</br>And oft in sweet communion prove</br>A blessedness beyond revealing.
5.</br>O!  how transporting then appear</br>The views Hope gives of future pleasure,</br>Beyond the realms of doubt and fear,</br>The saint's imperishable treasure.
6.</br>From thee, my Saviour, God, and King,</br>Let nought my happy portion sever;</br>But make it my delight to sing</br>Thy praise for ever, and for ever.

But not the magic of her voice alone</br>Held my rapt soul in willing thraldom there;</br>Her face with more than earthly beauty shone,</br>And dignity, and grace that none might share,</br>Blended with meekness in her modest air.</br>Now Hope aloft on golden pinions flew,</br>Unfolding scenes than paradise more fair,</br>To Faith's refin'd and heaven-directed view,</br>While Joy on all around unsullied radiance threw.

"O here," I cried, "from strife and tumult free,</br>Here would I ever find a resting place,</br>And joyful still my pilgrimage shall be,</br>Or short, or lengthen'd be its destined space.</br>Nor let me lose the sight of thy fair face,</br>Cheerful companion of my happiest hours;</br>Then, though temptation and strong trials chase</br>My harrass'd soul, to these delicious bowers</br>For refuge she may fly, and rest her weary powers."

"Well mayst thou wish," Content replied, "to prove</br>Th' exalted pleasures aye abounding here,</br>For oft descending from their seats above</br>To Faith's fixt eye angelic throngs appear,</br>Whose heavenly harpings never fail to cheer</br>The heart by sorrow or by pain opprest,</br>Lifting it far above each earthly fear</br>It views th' eternal mansions of the blest,</br>And a sweet earnest feels of everlasting rest.

"But know, that none this privilege may claim</br>But those whose bosoms truth and virtue fire,</br>Who live but to adore th' Almighty name</br>Of Him whose praise employs the seraph quire;</br>And such are blest with all their hearts' desire:</br>Spirits unseen surround their calm abode,</br>To ward off every ill, and to inspire</br>Such bliss as earth-bound thoughts had ne'er bestow'd,</br>Pure and devoted love of goodness and of God."

Next on the summit of the mount I stood,</br>And gaz'd around on stream, and grove, and bower,</br>Delighted, when my guide her speech renew'd:—</br>"Much yet remains of beauty and of power</br>To win thy fond regard, for every hour</br>That springs to life in this most sacred place,</br>Awakes some charm unknown before — some flower</br>More fragrant, or some new-born heavenly grace,</br>That gladdens every heart, and brightens every face.

"And ever on her own blest morn descends</br>The Angel of the Sabbath with her train,</br>And the glad sound of prayer and praise ascends</br>During her peaceful, septenary reign.</br>E'en now, in yonder grove, the hallowed fane</br>Re-echoes to the hallelujahs sent</br>From hearts aroused by her exalting strain.</br>Come, join the happy band."  Here ceas'd Content,</br>And towards the solemn spot our eager steps we bent.

High o'er the rest, like some imperial queen,</br>That angel figure sat; bright beams of joy</br>Illum'd her brow, unclouded and serene.</br>She spake of bliss that ne'er can know alloy;</br>(Which nought on earth can lessen or destroy,)</br>As the unchanging portion that awaits</br>The soul whose powers the wondrous things employ</br>Which Truth at her right hand to all relates,</br>While she their minds instructs, reproves, or animates.

Repose and Peace, that gentle pair, reclin'd</br>Beside the footstool of their heavenly friend;</br>A holy calm pervaded every wind</br>To which their grateful influence did extend:</br>And there in humble guise were seen to bend</br>Meek Piety and her devoted throng</br>Of followers, whose sweet voices seemed to blend</br>In choral harmony, while them among,</br>Rapt Contemplation stood, and listen'd to their song.

In Truth's fair hand methought a scroll appeared;</br>With characters obscure 'twas overspread,</br>And unintelligible sounds were heard</br>Fast flowing from her lips.  A secret dread</br>Crept through my frame, and I would fain have fled,</br>But had not power, — when suddenly a ray</br>Of light from heaven a noon-day splendour shed;</br>Clear and distinct the pictur'd chart now lay,</br>E'en as a map to guide the pilgrim on his way.

And first a garden it disclos'd, replete</br>With all that could delight the heart and eye,</br>Of Innocence and Peace the blest retreat;</br>And Joy flew ever through the cloudless sky.</br>But lo!  the fiend Transgression, lingering nigh,</br>Too soon involv'd the lovely scene in shade:</br>Then pass'd a long, dark train of ages by,</br>Laden with woe, by dread and doubt dismay'd,</br>While clouds and tempests dire were awfully pourtray'd.

Yet still, amid the gloom, one star was seen,</br>The Star of Promise, whose auspicious ray</br>In vain Despair essay'd to quench; serene</br>It rose, the earnest of a brighter day,</br>And many a heart it solaced on its way</br>Through the vast wilderness, nor shone its light,</br>Like the delusive meteor, to betray</br>The steps of fond Credulity, but bright</br>And certain was it beam through that long cheerless night.

Meanwhile, unnumber'd scenes of misery past,</br>Th' unfolding scroll to our delighted eyes</br>Display'd the dawning of that day at last</br>Whose glorious Sun, to set no more, should rise.</br>Unearthly music floated through the skies,</br>To usher in the morn.  Heavens concave rung</br>With the high theme — "Recover'd Paradise:"</br>Faith, long deprest, aloft exulting sprung,</br>While songs of joy and love enraptuid seraphs sung.

Then follow'd in succession, scenes so fair,</br>That to relate the wonders now reveal'd,</br>An angel's tongue might find employment there;</br>Or Inspiration's sacred pencil, fill'd</br>With hues of heaven, such images might yield:</br>But vainly may a son of earth aspire,</br>Duly to laud that mystery unseal'd;</br>Yet does the theme my inmost bosom fire,</br>And from the task I feel reluctant to retire.

Behold!  he comes — the Spoiler's Conqueror,</br>Though meanly wrapt, and in a manger laid!</br>A tender babe — yet Wisdom did not err:</br>She from afar led forth her sons, who paid</br>(While rich and precious offerings were display'd)</br>Their duteous homage, and pour'd forth their joy,</br>Rapturous joy, that might not be allay'd.</br>No more could doubt their peace of mind annoy,</br>Or fear, or dark despair their confidence destroy.

Wisdom, and Truth, and meek Humility</br>Led on his growing years, as through the lone</br>And silent valley of Obscurity</br>He held his peaceful course, to Fame unknown;</br>For on that scroll which such high things had shewn,</br>A transcript of the humble vale was given;</br>And shining tracks where holy men had gone</br>Unhurt, though they with deadliest foes had striven,</br>Might there be trac'd, whose light points out the way to heaven.

Unnoticed and unknown He seem'd to stray</br>Through the sequester'd haunts of solitude,</br>While Meditation cheer'd him on his way,</br>Till Time advanc'd with stated steps, and shew'd</br>A mind with heavenly wisdom deep imbued.</br>And lo!  emerging from the wilderness,</br>With solemn mien and warning voice One stood:—</br>"Flee from the wrath to come — repent — confess,"</br>He said, and pointed to the Source of blessedness.

"Behold," he cried, "the blest of heaven, with power</br>To bear away the ills which long have prest</br>Mortality, sunk deeper every hour</br>In misery's gulph; — but she shall now have rest."</br>He ceas'd, but soon the words he had exprest,</br>Methought I saw, confirm'd, for, lo!  a Dove,</br>Through opening heavens, descended to attest</br>That blest One's mission from the realms above;</br>And then a voice was heard breathing paternal love.

And next, a savage wilderness I saw,</br>Whose gloomy glades in fearful stillness frown'd,</br>And overwhelm'd my mind with solemn awe;</br>So wild, so dark, so drear was all around.</br>Led by the Spirit to this gloom profound</br>That Son of Heaven explor'd its deepest shade,</br>Musing on things divine.  There was he found</br>By the Arch Tempter, who in vain essay'd</br>To win his thoughts by wiles, with specious art displayd.

For in his mind revolv'd some great design;</br>And the false splendour of the world in vain</br>Before his eyes might bid its glories shine.</br>The heart opprest by sorrow to sustain—</br>To strip of all their terrors death and pain—</br>And sure and lasting happiness to spread—</br>These were the glories that adorn'd his reign:</br>And while by miracles He thousands fed,</br>Himself had scarcely where to rest his weary head.

Surely, thought I, there Gratitude soon raised</br>Temples, with joyful heart to celebrate</br>Such matchless power and love; but as I gazed</br>Upon th' expanding volume, seem'd to wait</br>On all his goings, Envy, Scorn, and Hate,</br>And ruthless Jealousy — a horrid crew;</br>Nor did their raging malice once abate,</br>But hourly fiercer and more deadly grew,</br>Unceasing, 'till at last their guiltless prey they slew.

Dark was the picture as it rose to sight;</br>In Mystery's stole enwrapt it seem'd to be</br>On every side, while Nature, with affright,</br>Beheld and trembled.  Meanwhile, patiently,</br>That injur'd One embrac'd wild Agony,</br>And mid the gloom, alone unshaken, brav'd</br>The howling storm.  Methought I then could see</br>That Sin, th' enslaver, felt himself enslav'd,</br>And gnash'd his teeth with rage, and impotently rav'd.

But short that reign of terror; soon he rose</br>Triumphant from the darkness of the tomb;</br>And then methought Confusion seiz'd his foes,</br>And wildly hurried to the distant gloom.</br>Again that Garden in primeval bloom</br>Appear'd, and Truth rejoic'd to shew the scene;</br>Rays of a purer light its walks illume;</br>And in the midst a gushing fount is seen,</br>In which Pollution foul may plunge and be made clean.

Fill'd with delight my heart within me burn'd</br>While Truth reveal'd to sight her wondrous lore;</br>Then, with reluctant steps and slow, we turn'd</br>The happy vale still farther to explore.</br>But ere I left, a wistful glance, once more,</br>I cast upon the glowing scenes around,</br>And gladly heard Hope promise to restore</br>Again and soon the joys I there had found;—</br>She said — "Such bliss once known will evermore abound."

Descending now the gentle slope, my eye</br>With pleasure wander'd o'er each tranquil scene.</br>That lay outstretch'd beneath a placid sky:</br>Westward some clouds befring'd with gold were seen</br>Marking where sunk the sun.  Stainless had been</br>The face of heaven but for that beauteous show,—</br>So bright — so calm — so lovely and serene:</br>I said, "If aught can picture forth below</br>The good man's latter end, mine eve beholds it now."

"But who," said I, " my courteous guide, is he,</br>Of thoughtful brow, yon cottage door beside;</br>His looks bespeak him what we seldom see</br>In this lone vale; say, does he here abide?"</br>"GENIUS his name, and here," Content replied,</br>In silent solitude pass on his days,</br>E'en as a stream that through dank weeds doth glide,</br>Unheard its rippling sound, unseen it strays;—</br>Such is his frequent lot, uncheer'd by Fortune's blaze.

"In his own breast the streams of pleasure spring;</br>And not less blest he deems his fate obscure</br>Here, than when shelter'd by the gilded wing</br>Of gay Prosperity, — if chaste and pure,</br>And lit from heaven his bosom-flame.  Secure</br>And happy in the treasures of the mind,</br>The thousand ills that little souls endure</br>Affect him not; but free and unconfin'd,</br>His spirit soars, and leaves each low-born care behind.

The sunbeams fell in glory round his head</br>As we advanc'd the gifted man to greet,</br>And while we sojourn'd 'neath his humble shed,</br>Of gentle manners, and of converse sweet</br>We felt the charm.  Around the calm retreat</br>Unbroken stillness reign'd; though there the hand</br>Of Application many an arduous feat</br>Achiev'd, and Truth and Fancy there had plann'd</br>Schemes that yield Taste delight, and Wisdom's smile command.

"Though in Obscurity's low valley cast,</br>My lot,'' said Genius, "is supremely blest;</br>From strife and envy free my days are past,</br>And Flattery's wiles seductive, aye confest</br>My deadliest bane, e'en when I seem at rest</br>With Fame, in yon bright temple on the hill.</br>Of Fortune's store I may not he possest;</br>Knowledge may deal with niggard hand his skill,</br>But while sweet peace is mine, this vale shall charm me still."

Now to my side, from mid'st th' industrious band,</br>Came Thought, a quick-eyed damsel, who delights</br>To dwell with Genius, and, at his command,</br>Oft takes, unseen, her swift and silent flights</br>Where aught new, great, or beautiful invites,</br>In nature, or in realms beyond; — then flies</br>Homeward, and with her gather'd store alights</br>In his fair mind.  And now, in friendly guise</br>She led me forth, and lo!  a garden met mine eyes.

There Fancy held her joyous reign, and there</br>Unnumber'd beauties burst upon the sight.</br>But how shall I my thrilling joy declare</br>When suddenly appear'd, like morning light</br>Breaking all lovely from the shades of night,</br>The nymph who had possest my heart so long,</br>And fill'd my night and day dreams with delight,</br>Enchanting Poesy, the maid of song,</br>Busied in culling sweets the beds of flowers among!

Content, who still stood near me, meekly smil'd</br>While I essay'd my transports to express;</br>Uncouth my manners and my words were wild,</br>For I was awed by so much loveliness:</br>When Poesy, to soothe my mind's distress</br>Thus spake, — "If these emotions be sincere,</br>Think not I scorn thy lowly lot to bless;</br>Whate'er its garb, true worth to me is dear,</br>Nor more so in the realm which Fortune sways, than here.

"But if the thought that I shall lead thee hence</br>To that warm clime, possess thy mind, 'tis vain;</br>Discard it; though the sunny eminence</br>Be more congenial than the lowly plain</br>To these my flowers, yet, see!  e'en here they gain</br>A beauty and a fragrance; and thine eye</br>Hath seen already that thou mayst attain</br>To true enjoyment: — while Content is nigh,</br>She, and yon mount's fair train shall all thy wants supply.

"And I will not forsake thee, but will cheer</br>Thy hours, or dark, or cloudless, as they rise;</br>Oft mid thy toil and care will I appear,</br>And bid my visions to thy view arise,</br>Whose wondrous imag'ry, and rainbow dyes</br>Shall charm thy inmost soul."  She ceased, and took</br>My hand, in courteous and benignant guise:</br>My mortal frame a thrilling transport shook,</br>And SLEEP, with sudden start, his silent post forsook.</br>
